BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Preparing the Atlas for launch is the same procedure are in Redstone (Lesson 1 and 2). The ascent is slightly different as there are an additional half-stage that needs to separate before tower launch and the final ascent before capsule separation. The ascent also takes 5 minutes to reach orbital speed.

CHECKLIST SYSTEM
The checklist system has been designed to provide you with all the checklists needed to fly and operate the spacecrafts in Reentry. All checklists are available from the CHECKLISTS tab of the Mission Pad. The checklist page has a few sections (headers such as ASCENT) used to categorize checklists.
You can open a checklists by clicking on it. This will show the checklist text, and you can start reading through it. You can use M to toggle the mission pad while you perform a checklist, or drag the checklist to the side of the window to give some more realestate to the panel, so you can work with it side-by-side.

Most checklists has a RUN button and a BACK button. BACK will bring you back to the checklist selection. RUN will allow a checklist guide system to help you through it. A switch highlighter will walk you through the checklist, highlighting out-of-place switches. The UI will show that step in the checklist you are at, and what switch needs attention.
In the Checklist Guide UI, the top line is the current checklist step needing attention, and the following lines are the queue of the next checklist items waiting for their turn. On the top line, the PRO button is short for PROCEED, and will tell the checklist system to move to the next line in the queue, completing the current line.

By default, the checklist system is configured to automatically proceed to the next line when a switch is placed to the correct position (basically pressing PRO for you). You can disable this autoproceed feature from the REALISM SETTINGS. If disabled, switched in the correct position will be highlighted in green, and you need to press PRO to continue.

There are two different checklist lines. One is a check to see if a control is in the correct position (such as a switch needed to be set to the UP position), or a fuse that needs to be closed.
Another type are manual steps. These steps are usually instructional (such as Perform a Radio Check, set up system X, ensure an instruments reads something). These lines have a flashing blue and green backdrop in the Checklist Guide UI. You need to manually press PRO to continue.

The Checklist Guide UI PRO button has a bindable hot-key to it, and is by default assinged to the keyboard button [T]. Pressing [T] will proceed the checklist to the next item in line.
Description: In this mission, you will use what you learned in the two previous lessons to launch the Atlas into space, and understand how the checklists work in your mission pad.

MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Atlas rocket. This is a much larger launch vehicle (LV) that the Redstone LV. It has enough thrust and propellant to take you into orbit around Earth.

Preparing the cockpit is the same as in Redstone, but today you will use the checklists found in the mission pad. Press [M] and read the BRIEFING tab for a primer in the CHECKLIST system, and click on the CHECKLISTS tab when ready.
By default, the only checklist you need to follow is the FINAL CHECKS checklist. Click on it. You can follow it manually, or click RUN. Do the latter now.

By default, the checklist auto proceed feature is on (toggle in REALSIM SETTINGS). If you RUN a checklist, a highlighter will walk you through the checklist. It will automatically proceed to the next step if the switch is in the correct position. Complete the checklist.
Now, go back on the checklist menu and select the ASCENT checklist. Monitor the gauges you learned in Lesson two (Battery Voltage, Fuel, Oxygen, Altitude, G force).
Another step in the Atlas ascent is the booster stage. This is considerd a half-stage, and will only remove some weight and our two booster engines once they are no longer needed.
Once the tower separates, we will do an additional step to prevent the retro engines to jettison accidentally.
Ok, the tower is gone, you are about halfway to orbit. The Sustainer Engine is now powering you for the final journey.
To prevent the retro engines to jettison by accident or failure, we set the AUTO RETRO JETT switch to off (right)
Good, then disconnect the power by opening the circuit using the Retro Jett fuse on the right side of the main manel.
Great, by doing this, you will have some additional security around your retro engines. They are your only tool to get back to Earth once you are in Orbit.
For the rest of the ascent, monitor the instruments and try to learn if you are ascending into orbit. The lesson ends when on capsule seperation.
Capsep! Good job, this concludes this lesson. You can end the mission using the ESC menu.

Title: Tutorial 3 - Checklists and Atlas Ascent
